Sense.DEF: if a sound or remark rings in your ears, you continue to remember it very clearly, exactly as it sounded, after it has finished
Sense.EXAMPLE: He left Washington with the president’s praises ringing in his ears.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他离开了华盛顿﹐总统的赞扬还在他耳际回响。

Sense.DEF: to telephone someone again, or to telephone someone because you were not available when they telephoned you
Sense.TRAN: 再（给某人）打电话﹔回（某人的）电话
Sense.EXAMPLE: I’ll ring back as soon as I find out anything.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我一发现什么情况﹐会再给你打电话的。
Sense.EXAMPLE: John rang, and he wants you to ring him back.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 约翰来过电话﹐他要你给他回电话。

Sense.DEF: to telephone the place where you work
Sense.TRAN: 给自己的工作单位打电话
Sense.EXAMPLE: Jane’s rung in to say she’ll be late.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 简来电话说她要晚到一会儿。
Sense.EXAMPLE: He rang in sick telephoned to say he was ill every morning for a week.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他有一个星期每天早上都打电话来说生病了。

Sense.DEF: to celebrate the beginning of the New Year
to end a telephone call
Sense.EXAMPLE: He rang off without giving his name.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他没留姓名就挂了电话。

Sense.DEF: a voice, bell etc that rings out is loud and clear
Sense.EXAMPLE: The sound of a shot rang out.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 传来一声响亮的枪声。

Sense.DEF: to celebrate the end of the year
to make telephone calls to a group of people, in order to organize something, find out information etc
Sense.EXAMPLE: I’ll ring round to see whether anyone’s interested in coming with us.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我会给大家打电话﹐看看谁有兴趣和我们一起去。
Sense.EXAMPLE: She rang round all the agencies.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她给所有的中介公司打了电话。

Sense.DEF: to telephone someone

GramExa.EXAMPLE: I’ll ring the manager up tomorrow.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 明天我会给经理打电话。

Sense.EXAMPLE: I rang up and made an appointment.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我打电话预约了一下。

Sense.DEF:
to press buttons on a
cash register
to record how much money is being put inside
Sense.TRAN: 把〔收进的钱〕记入现金出纳机
Sense.EXAMPLE: The cashier rang up £300 by mistake.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 收银员误把300英镑记入了现金出纳机。

Sense.DEF: to surround something
Sense.EXAMPLE: Thousands of people ringed the court building to demand the release of Mr Cox.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 数千人包围了法院﹐要求释放考克斯先生。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Her eyes were ringed with stiff black lashes.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 她的眼睛上有一圈硬挺的黑睫毛。

Sense.DEF: to draw a circular mark around something
Sense.EXAMPLE: Ring the mistakes in red.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 用红笔把错误圈出来。

Sense.DEF:
a
file
for holding papers, in which metal rings go through the edges of the pages, holding them in place
someone who rings church bells or hand bells
a piece of equipment that makes a ringing noise
Sense.EXAMPLE: Turn down the ringer on your phone.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 把你电话的铃声调低一点。

Sense.DEF: someone who pretends not to have a skill that they really have, in order to play on a team, enter a competition etc
Sense.TRAN: 〔比赛中谎称自己没有某种技能的〕违规参赛者

Sense.DEF: to decide officially that something, especially money, can only be used for a particular purpose
Sense.EXAMPLE: OK, so this £20,000 is ringfenced as the training budget.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 好吧﹐这两万英镑就作为培训专用的预算。

Sense.DEF:
the finger, next to the smallest finger on your hand, that you traditionally wear your
wedding ring
on
a ringing sound or voice is loud and clear
Sense.EXAMPLE: She pronounced her final words in ringing tones.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她把最后的几个字说得清脆响亮。

Sense.DEF: a statement that is made with a lot of force in support of something
Sense.EXAMPLE: a ringing endorsement of the proposals
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 对这些提案的有力支持

Sense.DEF: someone who leads a group that is doing something illegal or wrong
Sense.EXAMPLE: the ringleader of a new international drugs ring
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 一个新的国际贩毒团伙的头目

Sense.DEF: a long curl of hair that hangs down

the person who introduces the performers and animals in a
circus
the ring on the top of a can of drink that you pull to open it
a road that goes around a large town to keep the traffic away from the centre

the area nearest to the performance in a
circus
, a
boxing
match etc
Sense.TRAN: 〔马戏表演﹑拳击比赛等的〕台边区

Sense.DEF:
a seat very near to the performers in a
circus
, a
boxing
match etc

the sound made by a telephone, especially a
mobile phone
, when someone is calling it
a skin infection that causes red rings, especially on your head

a specially prepared area of ice that you can
skate
on

a special area with a smooth surface where you can go around on
roller skate s
to wash clothes, dishes, vegetables etc quickly with water, especially running water, and without soap
Sense.EXAMPLE: Let me just rinse my hands.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 让我冲个手。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Rinse the vegetables under a cold tap.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 把蔬菜放在冷水龙头下冲洗。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Don’t forget to rinse out your swimsuit.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 别忘了把你的泳衣冲洗一下。

Sense.DEF: to remove soap, dirt etc from something by washing it quickly with water
Sense.TRAN: 把 〔肥皂﹑污垢等〕冲洗掉﹐漂洗

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Leave the shampoo for two minutes, then rinse it off with warm water.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 让洗发液停留两分钟﹐然后用温水冲洗干净。
GramExa.EXAMPLE: I rinsed the mud out under the tap.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我在水龙头下把泥巴冲掉。

Sense.EXAMPLE: The cream rinses off easily.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这种乳液容易洗净。

Sense.DEF: to put colour into your hair

if you rinse your mouth, or rinse your mouth out, you wash it by filling it with water and then
spit ting
the water out
when you rinse something
Sense.EXAMPLE: I gave my hands a quick rinse .
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我很快地冲了一下手。

Sense.DEF: a product you use to change the colour of your hair or to make it more shiny
Sense.EXAMPLE: a blue rinse for grey hair
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 灰白头发用的蓝色染发剂

Sense.DEF: a situation in which a large crowd of people are behaving in a violent and uncontrolled way, especially when they are protesting about something
Sense.EXAMPLE: urban riots
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 城市骚乱
Sense.EXAMPLE: prison riots
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 监狱暴乱
Sense.EXAMPLE: His murder triggered vicious race riots caused by a problem between different races .
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他的被杀引发了严重的种族骚乱。
Sense.EXAMPLE: police wearing riot gear the special clothing and equipment worn by police officers during a riot
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 配有防暴装备的警察
Sense.EXAMPLE: police in bullet-proof vests and carrying riot shields a piece of very hard plastic which police officers stand behind to protect them
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 穿防弹背心﹑持防暴盾牌的警察

Subsense.DEF: if your imagination, emotions, thoughts etc run riot, you cannot or do not control them
Subsense.TRAN: 〔想象﹑感情﹑思绪等〕无法控制﹐不加约束
Subsense.EXAMPLE: Manufacturers have let their imaginations run riot to create new computer games.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 生产商极尽想象之能事﹐开发设计新的电脑游戏。

Subsense.DEF: if people run riot, they behave in a violent, noisy, and uncontrolled way
Subsense.EXAMPLE: Some people let their children run riot.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 有些人听任孩子胡作非为。

Subsense.DEF: if a plant runs riot, it grows very quickly

Sense.DEF: something with many different bright colours
Sense.EXAMPLE: The garden is a riot of colour in spring.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 春天花园里五彩缤纷。

Sense.DEF: to give someone a strong warning that they must stop causing trouble – used humorously
Sense.TRAN: 严厉警告（某人）必须停止闹事〔幽默用法〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: If the kids don’t settle down soon, I’ll go up and read them the riot act.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 如果孩子们不马上安静下来﹐我就要上去向他们提出严正警告。

Sense.DEF: if a crowd of people riot, they behave in a violent and uncontrolled way, for example by fighting the police and damaging cars or buildings
Sense.EXAMPLE: University students rioted in protest at tuition fees.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 大学生闹事﹐抗议学费过高。

Sense.DEF: noisy, exciting, and enjoyable in an uncontrolled way
Sense.EXAMPLE: a riotous party
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 狂欢聚会

Sense.DEF: noisy or violent, especially in a public place
Sense.EXAMPLE: Their riotous behaviour led to their arrest.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他们因暴乱行为被捕。

Sense.DEF: police whose job is to stop riots
Sense.EXAMPLE: Riot police fired tear gas into the crowd.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 防暴警察向人群发射催泪弹。

Sense.DEF: to tear something or be torn quickly and violently
Sense.EXAMPLE: Her clothes had all been ripped.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她的衣服都被撕破了。
Sense.EXAMPLE: The sail ripped under the force of the wind.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 船帆被狂风刮破了。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Impatiently, Sue ripped the letter open .
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 休急不可待地撕开信封。

Sense.DEF: to remove something quickly and violently, using your hands

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Gilly ripped out a sheet of paper from her notebook.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 吉莉从她的笔记本上撕下一页纸。
GramExa.EXAMPLE: The buttons had been ripped off.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 纽扣被扯掉了。

Subsense.DEF: to destroy something or damage it badly by tearing it in many places
Subsense.EXAMPLE: Jill’s kitten is ripping her sofa to shreds.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 吉尔的小猫在把她的沙发抓得稀烂。

Subsense.DEF: to strongly criticize someone, or criticize their opinions, remarks, behaviour etc
Subsense.TRAN: 严厉批评某人﹔抨击某人的观点[言论﹐行为等]
Subsense.EXAMPLE: I expected to have my argument ripped to shreds.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我等着别人来批驳我的论点。

Sense.DEF:
to copy music from a CD to an
mp3 player
or computer
to speak or behave violently or emotionally
Sense.TRAN: 激动地说﹔做出激烈的举动
Sense.EXAMPLE: Fran took a slow deep breath, then let rip, yelling and shouting at him.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 弗兰慢慢地深吸了一口气﹐然后发起威来﹐冲着他又喊又叫。

Sense.DEF: to make a car, boat etc go as fast as it can
Sense.EXAMPLE: Put your foot on the gas and let her rip!
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 踩油门﹐让它全速前进！

Sense.DEF: to tear or pull something to pieces
Sense.EXAMPLE: He was ripped apart by savage beasts in the forest.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他被森林里的猛兽撕得粉碎。

Sense.DEF: to charge someone too much money for something
Sense.EXAMPLE: The agency really ripped us off.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 代理商狠狠敲了我们一笔。

Sense.DEF: to steal something
Sense.EXAMPLE: Somebody had come in and ripped off the TV and stereo.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 有人进来偷走了电视机和音响。

Sense.DEF: to take words, ideas etc from someone else’s work and use them in your own work as if they were your own ideas
to move through a place quickly and with violent force
Sense.EXAMPLE: A wave of bombings ripped through the capital’s business district.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 首都商业区遭到一连串爆炸袭击。

Sense.DEF: to tear something into pieces
Sense.EXAMPLE: Sue ripped his photo up into tiny bits.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 休把他的照片撕得粉碎。

Sense.DEF: a long tear or cut
Sense.EXAMPLE: a green leather jacket with a rip in the sleeve
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 袖子有一条长口子的绿色皮夹克

Sense.TRAN:
the abbreviation of 缩写=Rest in Peace, written on a
gravestone
安息〔墓碑用语〕

Sense.DEF:
the string that you pull to open a
parachute
ripe fruit or crops are fully grown and ready to eat
Sense.EXAMPLE: Those tomatoes aren’t ripe yet.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 那些番茄还没熟。

Sense.DEF: to be ready for a change to happen, especially when it should have happened sooner
Sense.TRAN: 适宜做某事﹐做某事条件成熟
Sense.EXAMPLE: The police forces are ripe for reform.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 改革警察队伍的时机已经成熟。
Sense.EXAMPLE: The former dock area is ripe for development.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这片昔日的码头区可以开发了。

Sense.DEF: used to say it is a very suitable time for something to happen, especially when it should have happened sooner
Sense.EXAMPLE: The time is ripe for a review of progress up to now.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 是时候回顾一下目前为止所取得的进展了。

Subsense.DEF: if you live to a ripe old age, you are very old when you die
Subsense.EXAMPLE: Eat less and exercise more if you want to live to a ripe old age .
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 想长寿就少吃多锻炼。

Subsense.DEF: used to show that you find it surprising or impressive that someone is doing something or has achieved something at a very young age – used humorously
Subsense.TRAN: 年纪很小〔用于表示对某人很年轻便做或做到某事感到意外或惊叹﹐幽默用法〕
Subsense.EXAMPLE: She was put in charge at the ripe old age of twenty-nine.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她年纪轻轻﹐29岁就当上了主管。

Sense.DEF: ripe cheese has developed a strong taste and is ready to eat
a ripe smell is strong and unpleasant – used humorously
Sense.TRAN: 臭气熏天的﹐浓烈难闻的〔幽默用法〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: We were pretty ripe after a week of walking.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们走了一个星期的路﹐身上都臭死了。

Sense.DEF: to become ripe or to make something ripe
Sense.EXAMPLE: The apples were ripening on the trees.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 树上的苹果都熟了。

Sense.DEF: something that is unreasonably expensive
Sense.EXAMPLE: The meal was a rip-off and the service was appalling.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这顿饭贵得离谱﹐服务也糟透了。

Sense.DEF: music, art, films etc that are rip-offs copy something else without admitting that they are copies

GramExa.EXAMPLE: a rip-off of a hit movie
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 一部热门电影的翻拍作品

Sense.DEF: a quick, clever reply to something that someone has said
Sense.EXAMPLE: a suitably witty riposte
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 机敏而得体的回答

Sense.DEF: to move in small waves, or to make something move in this way
Sense.EXAMPLE: fields of grain rippling in the soft wind
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 和风中麦浪起伏的田野
Sense.EXAMPLE: I could see the muscles rippling under his shirt.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我看到他衬衫下面的肌肉一起一伏。

Sense.DEF: to pass from one person to another like a wave

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Panic rippled through Hollywood as the murders were discovered.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 数起凶杀案被揭露以后﹐好莱坞一片恐慌。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Enthusiastic applause rippled around the tables.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 席间热烈的掌声此起彼伏。

Sense.DEF: if a feeling ripples through you, you feel it strongly

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Anger was rippling through him so fiercely that his whole body shook.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 他怒火中烧﹐浑身都颤抖起来。

Sense.DEF: to make a noise like water that is flowing gently
Sense.EXAMPLE: The water rippled over the stones.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 石头上流水潺潺。
Sense.EXAMPLE: a rippling brook
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 潺潺的小溪

Sense.DEF: a small low wave on the surface of a liquid
Sense.EXAMPLE: ripples on the surface of the pond
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 池面上的涟漪
Sense.EXAMPLE: She dived into the pool, making scarcely a ripple.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她跳入池中﹐几乎没有泛起水波。

Sense.DEF: a sound that gets gradually louder and softer
Sense.EXAMPLE: A ripple of laughter ran through the audience.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 听众中笑声起伏。
Sense.EXAMPLE: a ripple of applause
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 此起彼伏的掌声

Sense.DEF: a feeling that spreads through a person or a group because of something that has happened
Sense.EXAMPLE: A ripple of excitement went through the crowd as he came on stage.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他走上舞台的时候﹐人群一阵骚动。

Sense.DEF: a shape or pattern that looks like a wave
Sense.EXAMPLE: ripples on the sand
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 沙上的波痕

Sense.DEF:
a type of
ice cream
that has different coloured bands of fruit, chocolate etc in it
Sense.TRAN: 山莓/巧克力等彩条冰激凌

Sense.DEF: a situation in which one action causes another, which then causes a third etc
Sense.EXAMPLE: The increase had a ripple effect through the whole financial market.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这次上涨在整个金融市场引起了连锁反应。

Sense.DEF: exciting and full of energy
Sense.TRAN: 喧闹的[地]﹐兴奋的[地]﹐欢闹的[地]
Sense.EXAMPLE: Micky had a rip-roaring time spending his first wage packet.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 米奇领到第一笔工资﹐痛快地玩了个够。

Sense.DEF: to increase in number, amount, or value
Sense.TRAN: 〔数字﹑数量或价值〕增加﹐增长﹐上升

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Sales rose by 20% over the Christmas period.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 圣诞节期间销售量增加了20%。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: The research budget rose from £175,000 in 1999 to £22.5 million in 2001.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 研究预算从1999年的17.5万英镑增加到2001年的2,250万英镑。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Temperatures rarely rise above freezing.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 气温很少升到零度以上。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: The number of people seeking asylum in Britain has risen sharply.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 到英国寻求政治庇护的人数激增。
GramExa.EXAMPLE: The divorce rate has risen steadily since the 1950s.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 20 世纪50年代以来﹐离婚率持续上升。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: The country faces economic recession and rising unemployment.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 该国面临着经济衰退和失业人数增加的问题。

Sense.EXAMPLE: The police seem unable to cope with the rising tide of large increase in car crime.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 面对日益增多的汽车罪案﹐警方似乎无能为力。

F2NBox.HEADING: REGISTER 语体
F2NBox.EXPL: In everyday English, people usually say an amount or level goes up rather than rises .
F2NBox.TRAN: 在日常英语中﹐表示数量或水准上升﹐人们一般用go up﹐而不用rise
F2NBox.EXAMPLE: Prices have gone up a lot.

Sense.DEF: to go upwards
Sense.EXAMPLE: The floodwaters began to rise again.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 洪水再次开始上涨。
Sense.EXAMPLE: She watched the bubbles rise to the surface.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她看着一个个气泡上升到表面。
Sense.EXAMPLE: the problems caused by climate change and rising sea levels
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 气候变化和海平面上升所引起的问题

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Smoke rose from the chimney.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 烟囱冒出烟来。
GramExa.EXAMPLE: The road rises steeply from the village.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 这条路从村子这里突然变陡峭了。

Sense.EXAMPLE: The waves rose and fell .
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 海浪起伏。

Sense.DEF: to stand up
Sense.EXAMPLE: Then she picked up her bag and rose to leave.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 然后她拿起包站起来要走。

GramExa.PROPFORM: rise from the table/your chair etc
GramExa.EXAMPLE: The chairman rose from his chair and came forward to greet her.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 董事长从座位上站起身﹐上前迎接她。

Sense.EXAMPLE: He put down his glass and rose to his feet .
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他放下杯子站了起来。

Sense.DEF: to become important, powerful, successful, or rich

GramExa.EXAMPLE: He rose to the rank of major.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 他升到了少校。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: He had swiftly risen to prominence during the 1950s.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 20 世纪50年代﹐他一下子就出了名。
GramExa.EXAMPLE: Mussolini rose to power in Italy in 1922.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 1922年﹐墨索里尼在意大利上台掌权。

Sense.EXAMPLE: people who rise to the top in their chosen professions
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 在自己所选择的职业中出人头地的人们

GramExa.EXAMPLE: He rose to become chairman of the company.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 他升为公司的董事长。

Sense.EXAMPLE: She had joined the company as a secretary and risen through the ranks made progress from a low position to a high position to become a senior sales director.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她初来公司时是一名秘书﹐后来逐步晋升为销售部高级主管。

Sense.DEF: to be very tall

GramExa.EXAMPLE: The cliffs rose above them.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 峭壁高耸于他们之上。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: huge rocks rising from the sea
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 耸立于海面的巨石

Sense.EXAMPLE: The bridge rose majestically into the air.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 大桥巍然矗立。

Subsense.DEF: to be loud enough to be heard

GramExa.EXAMPLE: The sound of traffic rose from the street below.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 下面的街上传来车来车往的声音。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Her voice rose above the shouts of the children.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 她的声音盖过了孩子们的叫喊声。

Subsense.DEF: to become louder or higher
Subsense.EXAMPLE: His voice rose in frustration.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他懊恼地提高了嗓门。

Sense.DEF: to appear in the sky
Sense.EXAMPLE: The sun rises in the east.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 太阳从东方升起。

Sense.DEF: if a feeling or emotion rises, you feel it more and more strongly
Sense.EXAMPLE: She could sense her temper rising again.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她感觉到自己的脾气又上来了。
Sense.EXAMPLE: There was an atmosphere of rising excitement in the school.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 学校里的气氛越来越热烈。
Sense.EXAMPLE: The doctor sounded optimistic and John’s hopes rose .
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 医生说得很乐观﹐约翰心中燃起了希望。

Sense.DEF: to deal successfully with a difficult situation or problem, especially by working harder or performing better than usual
Sense.TRAN: 成功应付困难局面/挑战
Sense.EXAMPLE: a young athlete who can certainly rise to the occasion
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 绝对能够应对困境的一名年轻运动员
Sense.EXAMPLE: The team rose to the challenge.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 球队挺身迎接挑战。

Sense.DEF: if a large group of people rise, they try to defeat the government, army etc that is controlling them
Sense.EXAMPLE: They rose up and overthrew the government.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他们揭竿而起﹐推翻了政府。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: The prisoners rose against the guards and escaped.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 囚犯制服看守后逃跑了。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: They rose in rebellion against the king.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 他们起来反抗国王。

Sense.DEF: if bread, cakes etc rise, they become bigger because there is air inside them
to get out of bed in the morning
to come alive after having died

GramExa.EXAMPLE: On the third day Jesus rose from the dead.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 第三天耶稣复活了。

Sense.DEF: if a court or parliament rises, that particular meeting is formally finished
if the wind rises, it becomes stronger
Sense.EXAMPLE: The wind had risen again and it was starting to rain.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 风又刮得更猛了﹐并下起雨来。

Sense.DEF: if a river rises somewhere, it begins there
Sense.EXAMPLE: The Rhine rises in Switzerland.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 莱茵河发源于瑞士。

Sense.DEF: used humorously to tell someone to wake up and get out of bed
if someone rises above a bad situation or bad influences, they do not let these things affect them because they are mentally strong or have strong moral principles
Sense.TRAN: 超脱﹐不受…影响﹔克服﹐摆脱
Sense.EXAMPLE: You expect a certain amount of criticism, but you have to rise above it.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 你会受到一些批评﹐但是你要泰然处之。
Sense.EXAMPLE: I try to rise above such prejudices.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我尽量不去理会这样的偏见。

Sense.DEF: if you rise to a remark, you reply to it rather than ignoring it, especially because it has made you angry
Sense.TRAN: 对〔尤指令人生气的话〕作出反应
Sense.EXAMPLE: You shouldn’t rise to his comments.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 你不应该计较他的评论。
Sense.EXAMPLE: He refused to rise to the bait react in the way someone wanted him to .
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他拒绝上钩。

Sense.DEF: an increase in number, amount, or value

GramExa.EXAMPLE: We are expecting a rise in interest rates.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们预计利率将会提高。
GramExa.EXAMPLE: an alarming rise in unemployment
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 失业率的惊人上升

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Profits went up to £24 million, a rise of 16%.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 利润增加到2,400万英镑﹐上升了16%。

Sense.DEF: an increase in wages
Sense.EXAMPLE: He’s been promised a rise next year.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他得到保证﹐明年加薪。
Sense.EXAMPLE: The railworkers were offered a 3% pay rise .
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 铁路工人得到3%的加薪。

Sense.DEF: the achievement of importance, success or power

GramExa.EXAMPLE: the rise of fascism
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 法西斯主义的兴起
GramExa.EXAMPLE: the rise of Napoleon
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 拿破仑的崛起

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Thatcher’s rise to power in the late 70s
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 撒切尔夫人在70年代末的上台掌权

Sense.EXAMPLE: The band’s sudden rise to fame took everyone by surprise.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 该乐队的突然成名让所有人都感到意外。
Sense.EXAMPLE: his swift rise to prominence
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他的一举成名
Sense.EXAMPLE: the rise and fall of the Roman Empire
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 罗马帝国的兴衰

Sense.DEF: to be the reason why something happens, especially something bad or unpleasant
Sense.TRAN: 引起[导致]某事〔尤指坏事〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: His speech gave rise to a bitter argument.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他的讲话引发了激烈的争论。
Sense.EXAMPLE: The President’s absence has given rise to speculation about his health.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 总统的缺席引发了对他健康状况的猜测。

Sense.DEF: a movement upwards

GramExa.EXAMPLE: a sudden rise in sea levels
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 海平面的突然上升

Sense.EXAMPLE: She watched the steady rise and fall of his chest.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她看着他的胸膛均匀地一起一伏。

Sense.DEF: an upward slope or a hill
Sense.EXAMPLE: There’s a slight rise in the road.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 路面有个平缓的上坡。
Sense.EXAMPLE: They topped the rise reached the top of the hill and began a slow descent towards the town.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他们登上山顶﹐然后开始慢慢下山朝小镇的方向走去。

Sense.LEXUNIT: get a rise out of sb
Sense.DEF: to make someone become annoyed or embarrassed by making a joke about them
Sense.TRAN: 〔开玩笑〕激怒某人﹔使某人尴尬
Sense.EXAMPLE: She enjoys getting a rise out of you.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她喜欢捉弄你。

Collocate.COLLGLOSS: great and sudden
Collocate.EXAMPLE: There’s been a sharp rise in house prices.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 房价急速上升。

Collocate.COLLGLOSS: great and sudden
Collocate.EXAMPLE: The meter showed a dramatic rise in the level of radioactivity.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 仪表显示辐射水平显著上升。

Collocate.EXAMPLE: The result was a huge rise in unemployment.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 结果是失业率大大增加。

Collocate.EXAMPLE: Manufacturers claimed the increase would mean a substantial rise in costs.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 制造商声称这一增加将意味着成本大大增加。

Collocate.COLLOC: a rise in the number of sth
Collocate.EXAMPLE: There has been a rise in the number of arrests for drug offences.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 因毒品犯罪而被捕的人数有所上升。

Sense.DEF: someone who usually gets out of bed very early or very late
the upright part of a step on a set of stairs
a set of wooden or metal steps that can be moved from place to place, used for a group of people to stand on
Sense.EXAMPLE: The school choir stood on risers behind the orchestra.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 学校合唱团站在乐队后面的活动阶梯平台上。

Sense.DEF: something that is risible is so stupid that it deserves to be laughed at
Sense.EXAMPLE: a risible suggestion
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 可笑的建议

Sense.DEF: becoming more important or famous
Sense.TRAN: 〔重要性或名望〕上升的﹐兴起的
Sense.EXAMPLE: Francesca was a rising star in the cinema.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 弗朗西丝卡是影坛新星。

Sense.DEF: young people who will soon be old enough to vote, have jobs etc
Sense.EXAMPLE: The rising generation of students are optimistic about the future.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 年轻一代的学生对未来很乐观。

Sense.DEF: a sudden attempt by a large group of people to violently remove a government or ruler
a condition where water comes up from the ground and gets into the walls of a building
Sense.TRAN: 〔由地面渗入墙壁的〕上升潮气

Sense.DEF: the possibility that something bad, unpleasant, or dangerous may happen

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Skiers always face the risk of serious injury.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 滑雪者始终面临着受重伤的风险。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: There is a risk that the disease may spread further.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 这种疾病存在进一步扩散的危险。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: There is no risk to public health.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 对公众健康没有危害。

Sense.DEF: an action that might have bad results
Sense.EXAMPLE: It was a risk, sending a letter to my house.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 将信寄到我家是冒险。

GramExa.GLOSS: do something that might have bad results
GramExa.EXAMPLE: Isn’t he taking a bit of a risk in coming here?
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 他来这儿不是有点冒险吗？

GramExa.PROPFORM: take the risk of doing sth
GramExa.EXAMPLE: I couldn’t take the risk of leaving him alone even for a short time.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我不能冒险留下他独自一人﹐哪怕是一会儿也不行。

GramExa.GLOSS: a risk you take because you think a good result is quite likely

Sense.DEF: something or someone that is likely to cause harm or danger
Sense.TRAN: 可能造成伤害[危险]的事物[人]

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Polluted water supplies are a risk to public health.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 受污染的水源对公众健康是一个威胁。

Sense.EXAMPLE: Meat from the infected animals is regarded as a serious health risk something likely to harm people’s health .
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 受感染动物的肉被认为对健康有严重威胁。
Sense.EXAMPLE: The tyre dump is a major fire risk something that could cause a dangerous fire .
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 那堆废轮胎是一个很大的火灾隐患。
Sense.EXAMPLE: She’s becoming a security risk someone who may tell important secrets to an enemy .
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她成了危险分子。

Sense.DEF: in a situation where you may be harmed
Sense.EXAMPLE: We must stop these rumours; the firm’s reputation is at risk.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们必须制止这些谣传﹐公司的名誉受到了威胁。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Women are more at risk from the harmful effects of alcohol than men.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 女性受酒精危害的可能性比男性更大。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Their children are also at high risk of developing the disease.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 他们的孩子患此病的风险也很高。

Sense.EXAMPLE: That would mean putting other children at risk .
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 那将意味着让其他孩子遭受威胁。

Sense.DEF: to be in a situation where there is a possibility that something bad could happen to you

GramExa.PROPFORM: run the risk of doing sth
GramExa.EXAMPLE: Anyone travelling without a passport runs the risk of being arrested.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 任何人不带护照旅行都有被逮捕的危险。

Sense.LEXUNIT: at the risk of doing sth
Sense.DEF: used when you think that what you are going to say or do may have a bad result, may offend or annoy people etc
Sense.EXAMPLE: At the risk of sounding stupid, can I ask a question?
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 恕我愚昧﹐能问个问题吗？
Sense.EXAMPLE: Will they go ahead with their plans, even at the risk of offending the Americans?
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他们会继续实行他们的计划吗﹐哪怕是冒着得罪美国人的危险？

Sense.DEF: if you do something at your own risk, you do it when you understand the possible dangers and have been warned about them
Sense.EXAMPLE: You can use it, but it’s at your own risk.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 你可以用它﹐但后果自负。
Sense.EXAMPLE: All personal belongings are left at the owner’s risk.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 所有私人物品﹐一旦丢失﹐责任自负。

Sense.DEF: a person or business judged according to the danger involved in giving them insurance or lending them money
Sense.TRAN: 〔按其风险评估的〕保险对象﹔贷款对象

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Drivers under 21 are regarded as poor risks by insurance companies.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 未满21岁的驾驶者被保险公司认为是高风险的保险对象。

Collocate.EXAMPLE: Professional sport involves a relatively high risk of injury.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 职业运动具有相对较高的受伤风险。

Collocate.EXAMPLE: The risks of failure are quite low.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 失败的风险很低。

Collocate.COLLGLOSS: one that is fairly large
Collocate.EXAMPLE: Starting up your own business involves considerable risks.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 自己创业风险相当大。

Collocate.EXAMPLE: There is a great risk that the wound will become infected.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 伤口感染的风险很大。

Collocate.EXAMPLE: Those who smoke have an increased risk of heart disease.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 吸烟者患心脏病的风险更大。

Collocate.COLLGLOSS: real and big
risks involved in something
might be dangerous
Collocate.EXAMPLE: Most medical operations carry some risk.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 大多数手术都带有某种风险。

Collocate.COLLGLOSS: might be dangerous
Collocate.EXAMPLE: Climate change poses serious risks to the environment.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 气候变化对环境构成极大的威胁。

Collocate.EXAMPLE: Investments that provide a high return generally entail more risk.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 高回报的投资一般必然伴有更多风险。

Collocate.COLLOCTRAN: 降低风险/令风险最小化
Collocate.EXAMPLE: This diet could reduce your risk of certain cancers.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 这一饮食方式会降低罹患某些癌症的风险。

Collocate.COLLGLOSS: remove risk completely
something that increases a risk
a calculation of how much risk is involved in something

Collocate.EXAMPLE: There is always a risk that mistakes will be made.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 犯错的风险总是有的。

Collocate.COLLGLOSS: some risk, but not much
Collocate.EXAMPLE: There is always an element of risk in flying.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 坐飞机始终存在一定的风险。

Collocate.EXAMPLE: Don’t walk home alone at night – it’s not worth the risk.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 晚上不要独自步行回家——这样冒险不值得。

Collocate.COLLOC: the risks involved/the risks associated with sth
Collocate.EXAMPLE: The soldiers were well aware of the risks involved.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 士兵们很清楚其中的风险。

Collocate.COLLGLOSS: they are more important than the possible risks

Sense.DEF: to put something in a situation in which it could be lost, destroyed, or harmed
Sense.TRAN: 使冒〔失去﹑毁坏或伤害的〕风险
Sense.EXAMPLE: When children start smoking, they don’t realize that they’re risking their health.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 小孩子学抽烟的时候并没有意识到这是在拿自己的健康去冒险。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: He’s prepared to risk everything to avoid this war.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 他准备不惜一切来避免这场战争。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: You’d be crazy to risk your money on an investment like that!
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 你疯了﹐竟然拿钱去冒险做那样的投资！

Sense.EXAMPLE: He risked his life helping others to escape.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他冒着生命危险去帮助其他人逃离。
Sense.EXAMPLE: I’m not going to risk my neck risk my life just to save a common criminal.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我才不会冒死去救一个惯犯。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Why risk life and limb risk your life and health jumping out of a plane just to raise money for charity?
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 何必为了慈善募捐去玩命跳飞机呢？

Sense.DEF: to get into a situation where something unpleasant may happen to you

GramExa.EXAMPLE: They may even risk losing their homes.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 他们甚至有可能失去房子。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: He would prefer not to risk another embarrassing defeat.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 他可不想冒再次失败丢人现眼的风险。
GramExa.EXAMPLE: Some people are prepared to risk imprisonment for what they believe.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 有些人为了信仰甘冒牢狱之险。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Workers who broke the strike risked being attacked when they left the factory.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 破坏罢工的工人在离开工厂时有遭受攻击的危险。

Sense.DEF: to do something that you know may have dangerous or unpleasant results
Sense.TRAN: 冒险做〔可能有危险或不好结果的事〕

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Are you prepared to risk traveling without an armed guard?
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 你准备冒险不带武装警卫出行吗？

Sense.EXAMPLE: She risked a glance back over her shoulder.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她壮着胆子回头看了一眼。
Sense.EXAMPLE: You could slip out of school between classes, but I wouldn’t risk it .
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 你可以在课间溜出学校﹐但我不想冒这个险。

Sense.DEF: not willing to take risks
Sense.EXAMPLE: Shareholders are more risk averse than they used to be.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 股东比以往更加不愿冒险了。

Sense.DEF: a system to prevent or reduce dangerous accidents or mistakes
Sense.TRAN: 风险管理〔避免或减少危险事故和错误发生的体系〕

Sense.DEF:
the practice of managing
investment s
in ways that produce as much profit as possible while limiting the danger of losses
Sense.TRAN: 风险管理〔指控制投资风险﹑实现最大利润的做法〕

Sense.DEF: when people do things that involve risks in order to achieve something
involving a risk that something bad will happen
Sense.EXAMPLE: Doctors say it’s too risky to try and operate.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 医生说动手术风险太大。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Buying a secondhand car is a risky business .
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 买二手汽车是有风险的。

Sense.DEF: a hot meal made from rice mixed with cheese, vegetables, or pieces of meat
Sense.TRAN: 〔用干酪﹑蔬菜﹑肉等烹制的〕意大利调味饭

Sense.DEF: a joke, remark etc that is risqué is slightly shocking, because it is about sex
Sense.TRAN: 〔笑话﹑言论等〕粗野的﹐近乎淫秽的﹐有伤风化的

Sense.DEF: cooked meat cut into very small pieces, mixed with potato or bread, and cooked in hot fat
Sense.TRAN: 〔加进马铃薯或面包的〕炸肉饼﹐炸肉丸

Sense.DEF: a ceremony that is always performed in the same way, usually for religious purposes
Sense.EXAMPLE: funeral rites
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 殡葬仪式
Sense.EXAMPLE: ancient fertility rites
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 古代的生殖崇拜仪式
Sense.EXAMPLE: These traditional rites are performed only by the women of the village.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这些传统仪式只由村里的女人来进行。

Sense.DEF: a special ceremony or action that is a sign of a new stage in someone’s life, especially when a boy starts to become a man
Sense.TRAN: 〔标志人生重要阶段的〕通过仪式﹔〔尤指男孩的〕成人仪式

Sense.DEF: final prayers or religious ceremonies for someone who is dying
Sense.EXAMPLE: A priest came to give him the last rites .
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 一位神父来为他做临终祷告。

Sense.DEF: a ceremony that is always performed in the same way, in order to mark an important religious or social occasion
Sense.TRAN: 〔为纪念重要宗教或社会事件举行的〕仪式﹐典礼
Sense.EXAMPLE: ancient pagan rituals
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 古老的异教仪式
Sense.EXAMPLE: the importance of religion and ritual in our lives
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们生活中宗教和宗教仪式的重要性
Sense.EXAMPLE: The lady of the house performs the sacred ritual of lighting two candles.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 由女主人来完成点燃两根蜡烛的神圣仪式。

Sense.DEF: something that you do regularly and in the same way each time

GramExa.EXAMPLE: the daily ritual of mealtimes
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 每天固定不变的进餐时间

Sense.EXAMPLE: He went through the ritual of lighting his cigar.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他按照老习惯点燃雪茄。

Sense.DEF: done as part of a rite or ritual
Sense.EXAMPLE: ritual dances
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 仪式舞蹈

Sense.DEF: done in a fixed and expected way, but without real meaning or sincerity
Sense.EXAMPLE: The police issued the usual ritual apology.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 警方发表了例行公事式的道歉。

RunOn.EXAMPLE: Animals are brought in and ritually slaughtered.

Sense.DEF: ritualistic words or behaviour always follow the same pattern, especially because they form part of a ritual
Sense.TRAN: 〔话语﹑行为等〕惯常的﹐例行的﹔（遵守）仪式的
Sense.EXAMPLE: a ritualistic procession
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 举行仪式的队伍
Sense.EXAMPLE: the ritualistic marking of birth, marriage and death
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 纪念出生﹑结婚和死亡的仪式

Sense.DEF: fashionable and expensive
Sense.EXAMPLE: a ritzy restaurant
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 高级时尚的餐厅

Sense.DEF: a person, group, or organization that you compete with in sport, business, a fight etc
Sense.EXAMPLE: This gives the company a competitive advantage over its rivals.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这使该公司与其对手相比具有一项竞争优势。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: his chief rival for the job
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 和他竞争这份工作的主要对手

Sense.EXAMPLE: He finished 39 seconds ahead of his main rival .
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他比主要对手早39秒到达终点。
Sense.EXAMPLE: She was 2 minutes faster than her nearest rival .
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她比紧随其后的对手快两分钟。
Sense.EXAMPLE: a game against their old rivals , Manchester United
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 和他们的老对手曼联队的比赛
Sense.EXAMPLE: They still remain bitter rivals hate each other .
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他们仍是死敌。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Their sales have now overtaken those of their arch-rival main or strongest rival .
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他们的销售额现已超过了主要竞争对手。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Sheena left her job and went to work for a rival company.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 希娜辞了职﹐转投一家对手公司工作。

Sense.DEF: one of a group of things that people can choose between
Sense.EXAMPLE: The newest model has several advantages over its rivals.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 最新的型号和其竞争品牌相比有几大优势。

Sense.DEF: to be as good or important as someone or something else
Sense.EXAMPLE: The college’s facilities rival those of Harvard and Yale.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这所学院的设施比得上哈佛和耶鲁。
Sense.EXAMPLE: a stadium to rival any in the world
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 世上一流的体育场

Sense.DEF: a situation in which two or more people, teams, or companies are competing for something, especially over a long period of time, and the feeling of competition between them

GramExa.EXAMPLE: There has always been intense rivalry between New Zealand and Australia.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 新西兰和澳大利亚之间总是存在激烈的竞争。

Sense.EXAMPLE: The two players have developed a friendly rivalry .
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这两名选手之间已形成一种友好的竞争关系。
Sense.EXAMPLE: She had never overcome her feelings of sibling rivalry rivalry between brothers and sisters .
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她一直没有克服和兄弟姐妹较劲的那种心理。

Sense.DEF: if a group of people are riven, they are divided by disagreements, especially in a violent way

GramExa.EXAMPLE: a community riven by religious differences
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 因宗教分歧而四分五裂的社区

Sense.DEF: if an object is riven, it is divided into two or more parts
a natural and continuous flow of water in a long line across a country into the sea
Sense.EXAMPLE: the Mississippi River
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 密西西比河
Sense.EXAMPLE: the River Thames
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 泰晤士河

GramExa.EXAMPLE: There were several boats on the river.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 河上有几条小船。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: We went for a walk along the river.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们沿着河边散步。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: a ship sailing up river
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 逆流而上的船
GramExa.EXAMPLE: They drifted slowly down river.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 他们慢慢地顺流而下。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: a bridge across the river
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 跨河的一座桥

Sense.HINTTRAN: Be careful about word order with river names 要注意河流名称的词序 – you say 可以说 the River Thames, the River Nile, the River Amazon etc, but 但以下河流要说成 the Hudson River, the Mississippi River etc.

Sense.DEF: a large amount of moving liquid

GramExa.EXAMPLE: a river of hot lava flowing from the volcano
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 从火山涌出的炽热熔岩流

Collocate.EXAMPLE: The River Avon flows through the town of Stratford.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 埃文河流经斯特拉特福小镇。

Collocate.COLLGLOSS: it flows in a particular direction
Collocate.EXAMPLE: the place where the river runs into the sea
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 这条河的入海口

Collocate.COLLGLOSS: it turns and curves, rather than going in a straight line
Collocate.EXAMPLE: He could see the river winding across the plain.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 他看见河流蜿蜒穿过平原。

Collocate.COLLGLOSS: it becomes narrower
it starts there
cross a river on foot, in a vehicle, or on a horse, without using a bridge
to travel along a river

Collocate.EXAMPLE: We crossed the wide River Rhone the following morning.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 第二天早上﹐我们渡过了宽阔的罗讷河。

Collocate.EXAMPLE: The Severn is the longest river in Britain.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 塞文河是英国最长的河流。

Collocate.COLLGLOSS: containing more water than usual
Collocate.EXAMPLE: After the rains, the river was swollen.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 雨后河水上涨。

Collocate.EXAMPLE: The child fell into a fast-flowing river.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 那个孩子掉进了湍急的河水中。

Collocate.COLLGLOSS: very big and impressive
Collocate.EXAMPLE: Cairo sits at the mouth of the mighty river Nile.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 开罗位于浩荡的尼罗河的河口。

Collocate.COLLGLOSS: people are able to travel along it in a boat

Collocate.EXAMPLE: Crowds lined the river banks to watch the boat race.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 人群站在河两岸观看划船比赛。

Collocate.COLLGLOSS: the bottom of a river
the land near a river
Collocate.EXAMPLE: He bought a house on the banks of the River Wye.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 他在瓦伊河岸边买了一栋房子。

Collocate.COLLGLOSS: where it joins the sea
Collocate.EXAMPLE: The Statue of Liberty stands at the mouth of the Hudson River.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 自由女神像坐落在哈得孙河河口。

Collocate.COLLGLOSS: the place where it starts

Collocate.COLLOC: the upper/lower etc reaches of a river
Collocate.COLLGLOSS: the upper, lower etc parts
it is very full and the water is flowing very quickly

Sense.DEF: an area from which all the water flows into the same river
the ground at the bottom of a river
the land along the sides of a river
Sense.EXAMPLE: We had a picnic by the riverside.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们在河边野餐。

Sense.DEF: if your attention is riveted on something, you are so interested or so frightened that you keep looking at it
Sense.EXAMPLE: All eyes were riveted on her in horror.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 所有人都恐惧地盯着她看。

Sense.DEF: to be so shocked or frightened that you cannot move
to fasten something with rivets
a metal pin used to fasten pieces of metal together
something that is riveting is so interesting or exciting that you cannot stop watching it or listening to it
Sense.TRAN: 令人着迷的﹔非常精彩的﹔引人入胜的
Sense.EXAMPLE: a riveting performance
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 引人入胜的表演
Sense.EXAMPLE: His story makes riveting listening.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他的故事让人听得欲罢不能。

Sense.DEF: a warm coast that is popular with people who are on holiday, especially the Mediterranean coast of France
Sense.TRAN: 法国/意大利/英国的海滨度假胜地

Sense.DEF: a very small stream of water or liquid

GramExa.EXAMPLE: rivulets of rain running down the window
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 雨水沿窗向下流淌的细流

Sense.DEF:
another spelling of
rial

Sense.TRAN: the abbreviation of 缩写=registered nurse注册护士
the abbreviation of 缩写=Royal Navy（英国）皇家海军
Sense.EXAMPLE: Captain Anstruther, RN
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 皇家海军安斯特拉瑟上校

Sense.DEF: an important chemical that exists in all living cells

a
cockroach
a type of European fish

the end part of a
marijuana
cigarette that has been smoked
a specially prepared hard surface for cars, buses, bicycles etc to travel on

GramExa.EXAMPLE: I was driving along the road when a kid suddenly stepped out in front of me.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我正在路上开着车﹐突然一个小孩冲到我车前。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: You’ll see the library a bit further up the road.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 沿这条路再往前走一点就能看到图书馆。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: I ran down the road to see what was happening.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我沿着路跑去看发生了什么事。
GramExa.EXAMPLE: My sister lives just down the road.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我姐姐就住在这条路上。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Protestors sat down in the road to stop the lorries.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 抗议者坐在路上﹐阻止卡车通过。

GramExa.PROPFORM: in the middle of the road
GramExa.EXAMPLE: Someone was standing in the middle of the road.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 有人站在路中央。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: I ran across the road to meet him.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我跑着穿过马路去迎他。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: The college is easily accessible by road.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 这所大学开车去很方便。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: There are far more cars on the road now than there used to be.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 现在路上的车比以前要多得多。
GramExa.EXAMPLE: There were lots of cars parked on the road.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 路上停着许多车。

Sense.DEF: used in addresses after the names of roads and streets
Sense.TRAN: 路〔用在地址中的街道名称之后〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: 65 Maple Road
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 枫树路65号
Sense.EXAMPLE: He lives on Dudley Road .
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他住在达德利路上。

Subsense.DEF: travelling in a car, especially for long distances
Subsense.EXAMPLE: I’ve been on the road since 5:00 a.m. this morning.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我从今早5点起就一直在路上。

Subsense.DEF: if a group of actors or musicians are on the road, they are travelling from place to place giving performances
Subsense.EXAMPLE: They’re on the road for six months out of every year.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他们每年有六个月在巡回演出。

Subsense.DEF: if your car is on the road, you have paid for the repairs, tax etc necessary for you to drive it legally
Subsense.TRAN: 〔汽车〕可以合法行驶〔指已付维修费用﹑税款等〕
Subsense.EXAMPLE: It would cost too much to put it back on the road.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 要让车子重新上路费用太高了。

Sense.DEF: if you are on the road to something, you will achieve it soon, or it will happen to you soon
Sense.EXAMPLE: The doctor says she’s well on the road to recovery.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 医生说她恢复得很好。
Sense.EXAMPLE: It was this deal that set him on the road to his first million.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 正是从这笔生意开始﹐他挣到了第一笔一百万。
Sense.EXAMPLE: the first step along the road to democracy
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 走向民主的第一步

Sense.DEF: to choose a particular course of action
Sense.EXAMPLE: Is there any scope for going down that road in the future?
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 今后还有可能那样做吗？
Sense.EXAMPLE: It depends which road you want to go down.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这取决于你想选择哪种做法。

Sense.DEF: in the future, especially at a later stage in a process
Sense.EXAMPLE: You can always upgrade a bit further down the road if you want.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 今后如果你想将电脑系统升级就能升级。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Somewhere down the road, they’re going to clash.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他们迟早会发生冲突。

Sense.DEF:
a last alcoholic drink before you leave a party,
pub
etc
Sense.TRAN: 〔离开聚会﹑酒吧等前喝的〕最后一杯酒

Sense.DEF: a situation in which someone experiences a sudden and complete change in their opinions or beliefs. The phrase is based on the story in the New Testament of the Bible, in which St Paul saw a blinding light and heard God’s voice while he was travelling on the road to Damascus. He immediately became a Christian.
Sense.TRAN: 通往大马士革之路〔指某人突然彻底改变观点或信仰﹐源于《圣经·新约》中圣保罗在前往大马士革途中皈依基督教的故事〕

Collocate.COLLGLOSS: with a lot of traffic
Collocate.EXAMPLE: The children have to cross a busy road to get to school.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 孩子们上学得穿过一条繁忙的马路。

Collocate.COLLGLOSS: with little traffic
Collocate.EXAMPLE: At that time of night, the roads were quiet.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 晚上的那个时候﹐马路上静悄悄的。

Collocate.COLLGLOSS: with no traffic or nothing blocking it
Collocate.EXAMPLE: Before you overtake, make sure the road is clear.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 超车前必须确定前路畅通。

Collocate.COLLGLOSS: an important road that is used a lot
a small road that is not used much
without much traffic or anything to stop you getting somewhere

Collocate.EXAMPLE: She was standing on the pavement waiting to cross the road.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 她站在人行道上﹐等着过马路。

Collocate.EXAMPLE: He had to swerve when a child ran out into the road.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 一个小孩子跑到马路上﹐他不得不突然转向。

Collocate.EXAMPLE: We turned into the road leading to the village.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们拐上了通往村子的路。

Collocate.COLLGLOSS: it turns and curves, rather than going in a straight line
starts going ahead in two different directions

Collocate.EXAMPLE: Her husband was killed in a road accident.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 她丈夫死于一起道路交通事故。

Collocate.EXAMPLE: We share parents’ concern for road safety.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们与家长一样关心道路安全。

Collocate.COLLGLOSS: knowledge of how to behave safely near traffic

Collocate.EXAMPLE: We stopped and had something to eat by the side of the road.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们停下来在路边吃了点东西。

Collocate.COLLGLOSS: in front of you
Collocate.EXAMPLE: The road ahead was completely flooded.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 前方道路整个被水淹了。

Collocate.COLLGLOSS: a place where a road goes in two different directions

Sense.DEF: a map that shows the roads in a particular country or area
Sense.EXAMPLE: a road atlas of Europe
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 欧洲道路交通地图

Sense.DEF: a place where the police are stopping traffic
Sense.EXAMPLE: The police have set up roadblocks to try and catch the two men.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 警方设置了路障﹐要抓捕那两个人。

Sense.DEF: something that stops the progress of a plan
Sense.EXAMPLE: mental roadblocks that get in the way of success
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 妨碍成功的心理障碍

Sense.DEF: someone who drives badly or too fast without thinking about other people’s safety
Sense.TRAN: 〔驾驶技术糟糕或不顾他人安全开快车的〕莽撞驾车者

Sense.DEF: a restaurant or bar on a main road outside a city
Sense.TRAN: 〔城外公路边的〕路旁餐馆﹐路旁酒吧

Sense.DEF: someone whose job is moving equipment for rock musicians
animals that have been killed by cars on the road
someone who makes arrangements for entertainers when they are travelling
Sense.TRAN: 巡回演出表演者的经纪人

Sense.DEF: an official plan to achieve peace in the future, that sets out what each country, government, group etc should try to do at particular stages along the way
a guide telling you about something, or telling you how to use or do something
Sense.EXAMPLE: a road map to the United States Constitution
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 美国宪法指南

Sense.DEF: a system in which drivers have to pay to use the roads at particular times
Sense.TRAN: 道路收费（制度）〔在某些时段收费以缓解交通堵塞〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: road pricing schemes for congested cities
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 针对交通拥堵城市的道路收费计划

Sense.DEF: violence and angry behaviour by car drivers towards other car drivers
Sense.TRAN: 公路暴怒﹐路怒〔指路上的驾驶者对其他驾驶者所表现出的暴力和愤怒行为〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: Road rage seems to be on the increase.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 路怒现象似乎越来越多。
Sense.EXAMPLE: a road rage attack

,

the process that a
mobile phone

a horse with some white hairs, giving it a light colour
to make a deep, very loud noise

Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们听到狮子在吼叫。
Sense.EXAMPLE: The engines roared.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 引擎轰鸣。

Sense.DEF: to shout something in a deep powerful voice
Sense.EXAMPLE: ‘Get out of my house!’ he roared.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: “从我家里滚出去！”他吼道。
Sense.EXAMPLE: The crowd roared in delight.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 人群高兴地叫喊。

Sense.DEF: to laugh loudly and continuously
Sense.EXAMPLE: By this time, Michael was roaring with laughter .
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这时迈克尔已经在狂笑了。

Sense.DEF: if a vehicle roars somewhere, it moves very quickly and noisily
Sense.EXAMPLE: The car roared off down the road.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 汽车呼啸而去。

Sense.DEF: if a competitor or team that was losing roars back, they start performing much better – used in sports reports

Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 下半场利兹队重振旗鼓﹐五分钟内连进两球。

Sense.DEF: a deep, loud noise made by an animal such as a lion, or by someone’s voice
Sense.EXAMPLE: the roar of the crowd
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 人群的喊叫声
Sense.EXAMPLE: He let out a roar of laughter .
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他放声大笑。

Sense.DEF: a continuous loud noise, especially made by a machine or a strong wind
Sense.EXAMPLE: the roar of the traffic
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 来往车辆的轰鸣声

Sense.DEF: making a deep, very loud, continuous noise

Sense.DEF: a fire that burns with a lot of flames and heat
to sell a lot of something very quickly

Sense.DEF: to be extremely successful

Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这部新音乐剧非常卖座。

Sense.DEF: very drunk and noisy

to cook something, such as meat, in an
oven
or over a fire, or to cook in this way
Sense.EXAMPLE: Are you going to roast the chicken?
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这鸡你是准备烤的吗？
Sense.EXAMPLE: the delicious smell of meat roasting
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 烤肉的香味
Sense.EXAMPLE: We caught a rabbit and roasted it over an open fire.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们捉到一只兔子﹐放在火上烧烤。

Sense.DEF: to heat nuts, coffee beans etc quickly in order to dry them and give them a particular taste
Sense.EXAMPLE: dry-roasted peanuts
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 干烘的花生

Sense.DEF: a large piece of roasted meat
Sense.EXAMPLE: a traditional Sunday roast
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 传统的周日烤肉

Sense.DEF: an outdoor party at which food is cooked on an open fire
Sense.TRAN: 户外烧烤热狗/牡蛎等野餐会

Sense.DEF: an occasion at which people celebrate a special event in someone’s life by telling funny stories or giving speeches about them
Sense.TRAN: 庆祝会〔常讲述主角的趣事等〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: a celebrity roast
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 名人趣事节目

Sense.DEF: roasted
Sense.EXAMPLE: roast chicken
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 烤鸡

Sense.DEF: very hot, especially so that you feel uncomfortable
Sense.TRAN: 灼热的〔尤指令人感到不舒服〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: a roasting hot day
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 酷热的一天
Sense.EXAMPLE: I’m absolutely roasting in this suit.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 穿着这套衣服﹐我真是热死了。

Sense.DEF: used for roasting food
Sense.EXAMPLE: a roasting dish
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 烤盘

Sense.DEF: if you give someone a roasting, you tell them angrily that you disapprove of their behaviour
Sense.EXAMPLE: He got a roasting from angry fans.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他遭到愤怒歌迷的斥责。

Sense.DEF: to steal money or property from a person, bank etc
Sense.EXAMPLE: They killed four policemen while robbing a bank.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他们抢劫一家银行的时候杀了4名警察。
Sense.EXAMPLE: A 77-year-old woman was robbed at knifepoint.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 一名77岁老妪遭到持刀抢劫。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: They threatened to shoot him and robbed him of all his possessions.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 他们威胁要开枪打死他﹐并抢走了他的全部东西。

Sense.HINTTRAN: You say that someone robs a person or place. Do not say that someone robs an object or an amount of money. Use steal. rob的宾语是人或地点。如宾语是物品或一定数量的钱﹐则不用 rob﹐而用 steal: He stole cash and valuables worth $500,000. 他偷了现金和价值50万美元的贵重物品。

Sense.DEF: to take money away from someone or something that needs it in order to pay someone else or use it for something else
Sense.TRAN: 拆东墙补西墙﹔剜肉补疮
Sense.EXAMPLE: Taking money out of the hospital’s budget for this is simply robbing Peter to pay Paul.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 将医院预算里的钱挪用到这里﹐简直是在剜肉补疮。

Sense.DEF: to steal everything someone has
Sense.EXAMPLE: The minute your back’s turned, they’ll rob you blind.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 你一转身﹐他们就会把你偷个精光。

Sense.DEF: used when you think that you were beaten unfairly in a sport
Sense.TRAN: 我/我们输得不公平！ 冤枉！〔用于体育比赛中〕

Sense.DEF: to have a sexual relationship with someone who is a lot younger than you – used humorously
Sense.TRAN: 老牛吃嫩草〔指跟比自己年龄小很多的人有性关系﹐幽默用法〕

Sense.DEF: to take away an important quality, ability etc from someone or something
Sense.EXAMPLE: The illness robbed him of a normal childhood.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 疾病使他无法拥有一个正常的童年。

Sense.DEF: someone who steals money or property
Sense.EXAMPLE: Armed robbers broke into the shop and demanded money from the till.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 持枪劫匪闯进商店﹐索要现金出纳机里的钱。
Sense.EXAMPLE: a bank robber
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 银行劫匪

Sense.DEF: a powerful person who uses their money and influence to get more money, business, land etc in a way that is slightly dishonest
Sense.TRAN: 强盗贵族〔指用自己的金钱和影响力攫取更多的金钱﹑生意﹑土地等的权贵〕

Sense.DEF: the crime of stealing money or things from a bank, shop etc, especially using violence
Sense.EXAMPLE: Police are investigating a series of bank robberies in South Wales.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 警方正在调查发生在南威尔士的连环银行抢劫案。
Sense.EXAMPLE: He received a 10 year prison sentence for armed robbery robbery using a gun .
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他因持枪抢劫被判十年监禁。
Sense.EXAMPLE: He admitted attempted robbery and was given a suspended sentence.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他承认企图行劫﹐被判了缓刑。

Sense.DEF: a long loose piece of clothing, especially one worn for official ceremonies
Sense.EXAMPLE: a priest’s robes
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 牧师的长袍

Sense.DEF: a long loose piece of clothing that you wear over your night clothes or after a bath
wearing long loose clothing
Sense.EXAMPLE: a robed figure
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 穿着长袍的人

GramExa.EXAMPLE: a man robed in black
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 身穿黑袍的男人

Sense.DEF: a small European bird with a red breast and brown back
Sense.TRAN: 欧亚鸲﹐知更鸟〔产于欧洲〕

Sense.DEF: a North American bird like a European robin, but larger

in old English stories, a man who lived as an
outlaw
in Sherwood Forest in central England, with his followers, known as his ‘Merry Men’. These included Friar Tuck, Little John, and Maid Marian. His enemy is the evil Sheriff of Nottingham, who is always trying to catch him. Robin Hood is usually shown dressed in green clothes, holding a
bow
. He is remembered especially for robbing the rich and giving to the poor, and people use his name to describe a situation in which money is taken from rich people and given to poor people.
Sense.TRAN: 罗宾汉〔英国传说中一个居住在英格兰中部舍伍德森林中的绿林好汉﹐因劫富济贫为人所知﹐故此人们以他的名字来表示劫富济贫的情形〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: a new higher-rate tax that will have a ‘Robin Hood effect’ on income distribution
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 将对收入分配产生“罗宾汉效应”的新式高税率税制

Sense.DEF:
the main character in the book Robinson Crusoe by Daniel Defoe. When Robinson Crusoe’s ship sinks, he manages to reach a
desert island a small tropical island with no people living on it
where he builds a home. Later he meets a black man who he calls Man Friday and who becomes his servant and friend. They are both finally discovered by a British ship and taken home. If someone lives alone on an island, people sometimes compare them to Robinson Crusoe.
Sense.TRAN: 鲁滨逊·克鲁索〔丹尼尔·笛福小说 《鲁滨逊漂流记》中的主人公。人们有时将独居小岛的人比作鲁滨逊·克鲁索〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: The explorer is a latter-day Robinson Crusoe.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 那位探险家是当代鲁滨逊。

Sense.DEF:
an
autodialler
a machine that can move and do some of the work of a person, and is usually controlled by a computer
Sense.EXAMPLE: cars built by robots
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 机器人制造的汽车

Sense.DEF: robotic equipment etc is related to robots or is part of a robot
Sense.EXAMPLE: the space shuttle’s robotic arm
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 航天飞机的机械臂

Sense.DEF: someone who is robotic acts like a robot by making stiff movements, not showing any human feelings etc
Sense.TRAN: 像机器人的﹔呆板机械的

Sense.DEF: the study of how robots are made and used
a robust person is strong and healthy
Sense.EXAMPLE: a robust man of six feet four
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 一个身高六英尺四英寸的壮汉

Sense.DEF: a robust system, organization etc is strong and not likely to have problems
Sense.EXAMPLE: The formerly robust economy has begun to weaken.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 原本强劲的经济开始疲软。

Sense.DEF: a robust object is strong and not likely to break

Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 结实的金属柜

Sense.DEF: showing determination or strong opinions
Sense.EXAMPLE: a typically robust performance by the Prime Minister
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 首相一如既往的坚定表现

Sense.DEF:
robust food or
flavour s
have a good strong taste
Sense.EXAMPLE: a robust cheese
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 味道浓郁的干酪

Subsense.DEF: the hard substance that forms the main surface of the Earth
Subsense.EXAMPLE: To build the tunnel, they had to cut through 500 feet of solid rock .
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 为了建这条隧道﹐他们不得不凿穿500英尺的坚硬岩石。
Subsense.EXAMPLE: Most of the country is desert and bare rock .
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这个国家大部分地区都是沙漠和裸露的岩石。
Subsense.EXAMPLE: massive rock formations shapes made naturally from rock
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 巨大的岩层
Subsense.EXAMPLE: ancient dark volcanic rock
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 古老的黑色火山岩

Subsense.DEF: a piece of rock, especially a large one that sticks up from the ground
Subsense.TRAN: 〔尤指凸出地面的〕岩块﹐大石块
Subsense.EXAMPLE: Jack stood on a rock for a better view.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 杰克站在一块大石头上﹐以便看得更清楚。
Subsense.EXAMPLE: During the storm a ship had been driven onto the rocks a line of rocks under or next to the sea .
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 暴风雨中有一艘船触礁了。

Sense.DEF:
a type of popular modern music with a strong loud beat, played using
guitar s
and drums

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Komuro formed a rock band with some friends while in college.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 小室在大学时期和几个朋友组建了一支摇滚乐队。

Sense.EXAMPLE: the late rock star, Freddie Mercury
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 已故摇滚乐明星弗雷迪·默丘利
Sense.EXAMPLE: The stadium has hosted numerous rock concerts .
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这个体育场举行过许多场摇滚乐音乐会。

Subsense.DEF: very strongly built or well supported and not likely to break or fall
Subsense.EXAMPLE: a large sofa, solid as a rock
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 一张稳如磐石的大沙发

Subsense.DEF: someone who is as solid or steady as a rock is very strong and calm in difficult situations and you can depend on them
Subsense.TRAN: 〔指人面对困难时〕坚定镇静的

Sense.DEF: someone who always gives you support and who you can depend on
Sense.EXAMPLE: My sister has always been my rock.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 姐姐始终是我可以依靠的人。

Sense.DEF: a relationship or business that is on the rocks is having a lot of problems and is likely to fail soon
Sense.TRAN: 〔关系〕濒临破裂﹔〔企业〕濒临破产
Sense.EXAMPLE: I’m afraid Tim’s marriage is on the rocks.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 蒂姆的婚姻恐怕是快破裂了。

Sense.DEF: an alcoholic drink that is served with ice but no water
Sense.TRAN: 加冰块的苏格兰威士忌/伏特加等

Sense.DEF: a hard sweet made in long round pieces
Sense.EXAMPLE: a stick of rock
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 一条硬棒糖

Subsense.DEF:
a very pure form of the illegal drug
cocaine
that some people use for pleasure
a small amount of this drug

Sense.LEXUNIT: be (stuck) between a rock and a hard place
Sense.DEF: to have a choice between two things, both of which are unpleasant or dangerous
if a man gets his rocks off, he has sex

a
diamond
or other jewel
to move gently backwards and forwards or from side to side, or to make something do this
Sense.EXAMPLE: She covered her face, rocking to and fro in her grief.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她捂住脸﹐悲痛得身体不住地来回晃动。
Sense.EXAMPLE: The waves rocked the boat from side to side .
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 波浪使小船左摇右晃。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Paul sat gently rocking the child in his arms.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 保罗坐着﹐轻轻摇晃怀里的孩子。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Jim rocked with laughter when he heard what had happened.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 吉姆听了发生的事情后笑得前仰后合。

Subsense.DEF: to make the people in a place or organization feel very shocked – used in news reports
Subsense.TRAN: 使震惊﹐使震动〔用于新闻报道中〕
Subsense.EXAMPLE: The scandal rocked the nation.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 丑闻震惊全国。

Subsense.DEF: to make the future of something seem less certain or steady than it was before, especially because of problems or changes
Subsense.EXAMPLE: Another financial blow has rocked the industry.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 又一次金融冲击动摇了这个行业。
Subsense.EXAMPLE: The theory rocked the foundations of social and moral life.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这一理论动摇了社会生活和道德生活的根基。

Sense.DEF: to cause problems for other members of a group by criticizing something or trying to change the way something is done
Sense.TRAN: 〔通过批评某事或试图改变做事方式而〕生事﹔找麻烦
Sense.EXAMPLE: He kept his feelings to himself, not wanting to rock the boat.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他没有把自己的感受说出来﹐免得惹是生非。

Sense.DEF:
if an explosion or
earthquake
rocks an area, it makes it shake
Sense.EXAMPLE: Residents had only a few minutes to escape before the blast rocked their houses.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 居民只有几分钟的逃离时间﹐随后爆炸就把房屋震得摇来晃去。

Sense.DEF: said to show that you strongly approve of someone or something
to cause someone to think about something or someone in a completely new way
Sense.TRAN: 动摇某人的世界〔使其以全新方式考虑某事物或某人〕

Sense.DEF: a type of music that combines rock music and traditional country music
to become as unhappy, unpleasant, or unsuccessful as it is possible to be
Sense.EXAMPLE: My personal life had hit rock bottom.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我的个人生活糟糕透了。

Sense.DEF: a rock-bottom price is as low as it can possibly be
Sense.EXAMPLE: bargain holidays at rock-bottom prices
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 最低价的特惠度假产品

Sense.DEF: the sport of climbing up very steep rock surfaces such as the sides of mountains

a
rocking chair

one of the curved pieces of wood fixed to the bottom of a
rocking chair
, that allows it to move backwards and forwards if you push it
to be crazy

a member of a group of young people in Britain in the 1960s who wore leather jackets, rode
motorcycle s
,and listened to
rock ’n’ roll
music
Sense.TRAN: 摇滚青年〔20世纪60年代英国穿皮夹克﹑骑摩托车﹑听摇滚乐的年轻人〕

Sense.DEF:
a musician who plays
rock ’n’ roll
music, or someone who likes this kind of music
Sense.TRAN: 摇滚乐演奏者﹔摇滚乐歌手﹔喜欢摇滚乐的人
Sense.EXAMPLE: ageing rockers
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 渐渐老去的摇滚乐歌手

Sense.DEF: part of a garden where there are rocks with small plants growing between them
a vehicle used for travelling or carrying things into space, which is shaped like a big tube
Sense.EXAMPLE: The rocket was launched from a space research base.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 火箭从一个太空研究基地发射升空。
Sense.EXAMPLE: a space rocket
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 航天火箭

Sense.DEF: a weapon shaped like a big tube that is fired at things
Sense.EXAMPLE: anti-tank rockets
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 反坦克火箭弹

Sense.DEF:
a
firework
that goes high into the air before exploding into coloured lights

a plant with green leaves and a strong taste, eaten raw in
salad s
Sense.TRAN: 大蒜芥﹔芝麻菜﹔紫花南芥

Sense.DEF: if a price or amount rockets, it increases quickly and suddenly
Sense.EXAMPLE: Interest rates rocketed up.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 利率飞涨。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Car sales rocketed from 180 to 2,000 a year.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 汽车的年销量从180辆猛增到2,000辆。

Sense.DEF: to move somewhere very fast
Sense.EXAMPLE: The train rocketed through the tunnel.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 火车高速穿过隧道。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Larsson’s shot rocketed into the back of the net.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 拉森射出的球直飞网底。

Sense.DEF: to achieve a successful position very quickly
Sense.TRAN: 迅速取得成功﹔一举成名

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Their new album rocketed to number one in the charts.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 他们的新专辑跃居排行榜首位。
GramExa.EXAMPLE: Beatty rocketed to stardom after his first film.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 贝蒂拍摄首部电影后迅速蹿红。

Sense.DEF: used to say that something is not difficult to do or understand
Sense.EXAMPLE: Designing a website may be a lot of work but it’s not rocket science.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 设计一个网站可能很费功夫﹐但并非难事。

Sense.LEXUNIT: it doesn’t take a rocket scientist (to do sth)
Sense.DEF: used humorously to emphasize that something is easy to do or understand
Sense.EXAMPLE: It doesn’t take a rocket scientist to work out that doubling productivity will improve profits.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 生产效率提高两倍可以增加利润﹐这并不难理解。

Sense.DEF: someone who is extremely clever
a scientist whose work is related to rockets
a very steep surface of rock on the side of a mountain
a pile of rocks that are falling or have fallen

a
rockery
extremely hard
Sense.EXAMPLE: The bread was stale and rock-hard.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这个面包不新鲜﹐硬邦邦的。

Sense.DEF: strong and not afraid of anyone – used humorously
Sense.TRAN: 坚强的﹔谁也不怕的〔幽默用法〕

Sense.DEF: a chair that has two curved pieces of wood fixed under its legs, so that it moves backwards and forwards smoothly
a wooden horse for children that moves backwards and forwards when you sit on it

a type of popular modern music with a strong loud beat, played using

and drums

a style of music with a strong loud beat played on
guitar s
